Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: HanCraft-based Hand Gesture Controlled Robotic Toy Platform for Gender Neutral STEM Learning
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop and test a new craft-based hand gesture controlled robotic toy platform and accompanying game scenarios to engage students, in particular girls, from middle and high schools in STEM cognate fields of physics and engineering design. According to NAEP 2009 data, only a small percentage of the students - 34% of 4th graders, 30% of 8th graders, and 21% of 12th graders performed at or above the proficient level in science. Science and Engineering Indicators show that less than 40% of students have taken some physics and less than 10% have taken engineering in high school. This poses a serious challenge to the global competitiveness of US. While Robotics can be effective in STEM education it is mostly popular among boys. However crafting and electronic textile communities tend to attract girls. This proposed innovation allows kids to create custom robotic parts out of craft material, easily assemble them and control them using hand gestures.

This project aims to develop and test a cyber-physical 'craft-based' hand gesture controlled robotic toy platform for STEM learning that is gender neutral. It combines handcrafting/making, electronics, robotics, gesture interfaces and interactive gaming scenarios to enable middle and high school students to learn STEM. Kids can use the kit to make any toy of their imagination using everyday objects as material and play with them using hand gestures. Phase I of this project focuses on (1) developing new design capabilities for the play value with the kit (2) create proof-of-concept play/game scenarios and (3) conduct preliminary testing to demonstrate gender neutrality, learning, engagement and play-value the kit offers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase I project developed and tested the prototype for a new craft-based hand gesture controlled robotic toy platform “HandiMake” and accompanying use case scenarios to engage students, in particular girls, from middle and high schools in STEM cognate fields of physics and engineering design. HandiMake innovation allows kids and students of ages 8 to 15 to create custom robotic parts out of craft material, easily assemble them using joint modules and control them using hand gestures with glove controller.  HandiMake system consists of (1) Wireless motor modules (2) Smart glove controller (3) Mobile application for configuration of glove. 

The following objectives were successfully completed: (1) extended HandiMake prototype kit was built (2) game competition and use case scenarios were created and implemented (3) hypothesis testing for gender appropriateness, usability, engagement and learning was conducted. (4) designed and implemented a new Bluetooth 4.0 based architecture that increases playtime of the previous XBee based prototype while reducing the over all cost for wider consumer acceptability.  The proposed hypothesis that craft-based toy construction kit with greater creative freedom using everyday objects as materials, hand gesture control using mobile configurable glove, using the robotic toy kit would attract and engage kids in STEM was successfully validated. Gender neutraity of Handimake was validated in comparative user study.
